citation.article-title: Reclassification of Brevibacterium incertum (Breed 1953) as Desemzia incerta gen. nov., comb. nov.

p.s: Description of Desemzia gen. nov.
Desemzia (De.sem'zi.a. M.L. fem., arbitrary name, derived from the abbreviation DSMZ (Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen Gm bH))
Morphological, cultural and physiological properties are those of Jones & Keddie (1 986), who combined the original data of Steinhaus (1941) and Breed (1953).
The chemotaxonomic data have been published by Collins & Kroppenstedt (1983).
Short rods, 0.5-0.8 x 1.0-1.5 μm, occurring singly and occasionally in pairs.
Gram-positive.
Cells from older cultures tend to lose the ability to retain the Gram stain.
Not acid-fast.
Endospores not formed.
Microaerophilic.
Metabolism fermentative.
L-Lactic acid but no D-lactic acid is produced from glucose.
Catalase-negative, oxidasenegative.
The peptidoglycan contains lysine as the diagnostic amino acid (peptidoglycan type L-lysine-D-glutamic acid; variation A4α).
Mycolic acids are not present.
Isoprenoid quinones not present.
The fatty acids are composed of predominantly straight chain saturated and monounsaturated acids.
The major fatty acids are hexadecanoic (C16:0), hexadecenoic (C16:1) and cis-vaccenic (C18:1, ω7).
The G+C content of the DNA is 40 mol%.
Phylogenetically, a member of the Bacillus-Lactobacillus group of the subphylum Clostridium-Bacillus, phylum of Gram-positive bacteria, domain Bacteria.
Isolated from the ovaries of the lyreman cicada, Tibicen linnei.
Habitat is not known.
The type species is Desemzia incerta comb. nov.
